description: In Property Tycoon, players move around the board and buy property using a hidden bid system. Players do not know who they are bidding against — if anyone — as only one player has to reveal intent. You can be financially ruined and out of the game before you even start on the property ladder.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Crazy Circles
description: Crazy Circles is a colorful game for 5 year olds and upwards. It is very easy to play but very frustrating. You simply have to get from the start to the finish -- easy? There is no skill required for this game -- just a lot of luck and a desire to have some fun.

name: Burns and Verse
description: Burns and Verse comprises 10 beautiful images of the great poet Robert Burns and/or associates complemented with a wonderful verse. Burns and Verse can be enjoyed as a game amongst friends, or pieced together by lovers of Burns poetry.

name: Morgan Junior: The Race Is On
description: Based loosely on Shannon Boardgames previous game of paying attention while traveling -- I-Spy. Players are trying to be the first to make it past the finish line.

name: Scamp
description: "Scamp" is a game about Guide Dogs created specially for the "Guide Dogs for the Blind" association. The object is to make it from your home to the park whilst keeping your guide dog by your side.

name: Falkirk Wheel
description: "The Falkirk Wheel" is a game commissioned by "British Waterways Scotland" to be sold in the gift shop housed in the Falkirk Wheel complex, which was opened in 2002. This is a simple game mimicking the wheel's rotational movement.

name: Bottoms Up
description:
From Box
"A classic game played on a checker board and combining some of the choice aspects of chess, droughts, poker and bridge. yet so easy to learn everyone achieves competence sufficient for enjoyment during the first game. Accommodates 2,3 or 4 players
at once."

The object of the game is to accumulate the highest score, which is not necessarily the same as capturing all of one's opponent's pieces.

Moves: Any counter or piece may be moved exactly like a chess queen however limited to the number of squares moved at a single turn by the number on its bottom. that is a counter may be moved perpendicular to the sides of the squares or along the diagonals provided there is no obstruction but limited by the number on the bottom.
General Rule: Any piece moved more than one square on a single turn of a player must be turned and played bottom up for the remainder of the game .... capture is the same as in chess .... a players score is the sum of the numbers on the bottoms of the opposing pieces he/she has captured plus the sum of the numbers on his/her own counters remaining on the board at end.
etc etc

name: Pago Pago
description:
"There's never been anything like this crossword puzzle game!" That seems likely...

The game consists of three large sheets of paper, with each four different crossword puzzles on each side of each sheet. Two to four (as two teams) players work the puzzle on their side of the square sheet for three minutes, each with their own colored pencil. When time is up, the sheet is rotated 90 degrees, the timer is reset, and the players work the new (to them) puzzle now on their side.

You keep adding letters and/or correcting mistakes, then rotating every three minutes until the puzzles are completed or everyone gives up. You get points for correct letters you've added, and you subtract points for errors noted by your opponents. The colored pencils allow end-of-game scoring and adjudication of the puzzles. Answers are provided in sealed envelopes.

Seems like it would be fun, but you'd really have to love crosswords - working them with time pressure is sweet misery. Six games can be played by four players with the supplied puzzles. Refill puzzles were available in 1985 using the handy order form, but good luck now.

name: Flip-It 7-11
description:
A dice game that features a disc shooting mechanism to generate dice rolls. The game board also supports play as a standard craps table.
The game features Flip Wilson on the cover.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Number

name: Armored Attack: 1939 to 1990
description:
A set of miniatures rules for Tanks skirmish level historical wargaming (1 stand = 1 tank, 1 stand = squad/ldr/weapon team)

Movement is simultaneous.

Fire Order is determined by assigning units to cards and shuffling the deck and turning over the card.
Fire order is then enhanced by an initiative roll.
Contains lots of ratings for weapons/vehicles from WW2 through the mid-80's
categories: Book, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame, World War II

name: Wir Gehören zusammen!
description: A fun children's game about how to properly deal with dogs. The game includes a set of colorful cards depicting situations that a child could encounter with dogs, such as two dogs fighting, etc. The player must then play a card which shows the proper response to the action. There are cards that show both right and wrong reactions.

name: Sandwiching Game
description: The full name of this game is the "Addition, Multiplication, Calculation Sandwiching Game". The board is two sided and each side shows a 9 x 9 grid. One side is for addition and the other for multiplication. Players place pieces on the grid and try to roll combinations that will remove other players' pegs. A Japan Brain Sports Association winner.

name: Rhino!
description: A game with beautiful wooden Rhinos that uses the same ideas as Wittigs' Mary Pennylane and Raina. Players try to pull the Rhinos toward a goal using a die that determines which rope can be held. The Rhino is pulled until caught.

name: Desert Dice
description: A unique dice dexterity game that uses a large wooden frame holding real sand. Dice of various sizes are buried in the sand, and players use magnetic rods to pull up dice of specific values to score points.

name: Plumino
description: Mathematical brains, this is for you! With correct addition or subtraction, you can exchange your game pieces on the flower. Exciting reckoning using 1-10 made easy.

name: Tunelino
description: The travelers on the train are going on a long journey today. First of all, the train must be hooked together. The reward for being a successful engineer is to ride through the tunnel.

name: Scolina
description: An entertaining learning game with a built-in key to check the solutions to problems. Learning by playing is fun: find the pairs, sort the shapes and colors, and put things in order.

name: Popsicle Zone Games
description: Three games in one. Game one: the coolest hoppin' Popsicle party ever! Collect the most Popsicles. Game two: The Popsicle 500 race game. Get in gear and hurry around the game board. Game three: Popsicle or President? To win the election, get out there and collect votes!

name: Atrio
description:
Atrio is played on an octagon with 3 marbles per player. Pieces are pushed away by playing a dark marble. The first player who gets his marbles in the inner circle or who ousts one of the opponent's marbles off the board (beyond the large circle) wins

Atrio was designed by Christian Gibon (France) and first published in 1997 by LM Créations.

Rules: http://maisonauteursdejeu.free.fr/Site.MAJ/LesJeux/ATRIO/Pre...

name: Kopf an Kopf
description: An eye feast for the culturally interested. The game idea is traditional memory matching. The 80 cards show costumes as well as photos of statues, sculptures and paintings. Beautiful, fascinating photos of different time epochs come from the Rietberg Museum in Zurich. An accompanying booklet gives information about all of the photos.

name: Tempora
description: Tempora is a game about moving through different times. How have people experienced different cultures and lives during different times? "You have the clocks, we have the time": this African sentence was made at the address of Europeans and this inspired the game. A game with clocks and beautiful pictures from all over the world.

name: Das Bus Spiel
description: A game with large wooden pieces representing buses. The game is played on the floor. The "board" is the whole room. The buses go from stop to stop, and the winner is the player who can first deliver three multi colored passengers to their destination.

name: Flickers!
description:
Flickers! is the first game of the Canadian-owned company Eagle Games Ltd. From their website:

Flickers!, the movie trivia game that leaves nothing to chance!

Flickers (slang): a motion picture.

That explains the name of the game. But why do we call it the movie trivia game that leaves nothing to chance? Because in this game, the element of chance has been eliminated. There are no traditional dice to indicate space moves on aboard; there are no exact number requirements to win the game and there are no free rolls of a dice.

The only playing piece is a color-coded cube corresponding to movie categories.

Flickers! is scored, and won, solely on your knowledge of the movies. You score points (or lose them) based on what you know about the movies, from home-grown fare to foreign treats, from the 1930s to the present.

Flickers! has been created and designed to be fun for the casual once-a-month movie goer as well as challenging enough for the avid movie-a-week film buff.

Flickers! can be played by any number of adult players, anytime, anywhere. It can be played by individuals, or in teams. It can be played at the dining-room table, in the park, or in the back seat of a car on a road trip.

And if any of the question and answer cards pique your curiosity, go out and rent the movie. You may have no idea what delights you are missing when you don't explore all the genres from all the decades, and the works of stars past and present.

Above all, enjoy.....the movies and Flickers!

name: Scarecrow Target Game
description:
The original 1965 release comes in a very large 19" x 18" x 8" box. It features a plastic scarecrow (which is almost as large as the box) with various scoring targets - hat (5 points), crows on arms (10 or 15 points) and a 50 point target on the scarecrow's coat which, when hit, causes the scarecrow's coat to fall off in pieces. A dart gun with three suction-cup darts is also included.

A turn consists of firing all three darts at the scarecrow from a pre-agreed distance. If a player causes the coat of the scarecrow to fall off, 50 points is scored and their turn ends, regardless of the number of darts in reserve.

The first player to accumulate 300 points is the winner.

Game was re-released in 1975 in a very slightly different box.

name: Four Over
description: The Four Over Game claims to take the skill of pinball and the logic of checkers. Flip the steel ball to find out how many moves, then move your checkers across the board to the other player's home. The ball may knock some checkers out as it falls into the numbered slot.

name: Nordi
description:
The theme of this game is smuggling cigars, wine, rum, watches, cigarettes and money between Germany, Austria and Switzerland on skis! Thus, an unusual theme for the alps...

There are 3 home bases, where the players can buy up to 3 smuggling goods and start their way to deliver them to another base. Movements are not done by a dice roll, but the more goods a player is carrying, the slower will be his speed. this can be dangerous, because their is a fast moving frontier-guard, who will confiscate the goods, when he catches a player.

Before starting, the players should know, which smuggling goods give the best profit - watches are cheap to buy in Switzerland and give the most in Germany for example.

The game has double sided playing money, which comes in the (old) currencies of the 3 countries: Deutsche Mark, Schilling and Schweizer Franken.

name: Play Cavalry
description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, who come in a square plastic box (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric).

Play Ecology looks like a mixture of "Trap the Cap" and "Chess", but it is not as easy as that sounds. Each of the players has 6 playing pieces, which move like the Knights in chess. In the middle of the board is one neutral piece, who carries a wooden ball on his crater shaped top.

Object of the game is to catch that wooden ball (the playing pieces all have small craters on their top to put the ball on top) and bring it to your edge of the 9x9 game board. The neutral piece moves like the king in chess and it can make captures by jumping on other pieces - like in "Trap the Cap". What makes the game interesting is, that the neutral piece is the only piece that can capture normal pieces. That means, that you need at least 1 piece to capture the ball, but the other pieces can only try to block other pieces from doing so.

name: Play Balance
description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, which come in a square plastic board (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric).

The board has 12x12 spaces and each of them is made as a 3d-hole, where you can place a tile looking to one player or to the other by tip over the tile.

One player plays with the 48 water tiles and the other takes the 48 land tiles. Each tile can be moved 1 space in advance. Captures (accomplished sideways) can be done when a tile can move to an empty space, which has an opponents tile directly adjacent to it. Since the tiles are facing in 2 directions, the rules use the term "overshadowed" for such tiles. The capture is done by tipping over the captured piece and if there are additional tiles directly behind the captured piece, you can tip over these tiles also.

The game ends, when all positions are blocked, that is when no reasonable moves can be made by neither player. You simply count the tiles then to see, if the water or land player has won the game.

name: Pick a Peg
description:
The game is played on a hex board, which has 97 holes. The board is placed upright on a plastic base and all 97 holes must be filled with 97 pegs. The pegs have to be placed so that both ends overhang the same length on both sides of the board.

Each player sits on one side of the vertical board and before starting, each must secretly hang his red playing piece on one of the 97 pegs.

Each turn, a player now takes off 1 peg off the board and he is free to turn the board by 60 degrees before taking a peg off.

The 2 playing pieces are formed like a horseshoe and if the opponent takes off a peg with a horseshoe hanging on it, it will fall down to the next peg - or on the table, if none is below. Winner is the player who succeeds in letting the opposing horseshoe fall on the table.

name: Tesseract
description:
This game has a 16x16 game board, but the playing pieces move on the 15x15 intersections.

The second and third row on each side of the board are the player's home sections, the space between is neutral. Each player has 6 "normal" playing pieces (1 tesseract, 1 cylinder, 1 pyramid, 1 rectangle, 2 stars), 2 large slide bars, 5 small slide bars and 2 crosses.

At the start, each player places the Tesseract, the pyramid, one star and 2 small slide bars in his section. Then the 2 crosses are placed in the neutral zone. These crosses cannot be moved and remain at their position until the end of the game. The remaining pieces: the cylinder, the rectangle, one star and 5 slide bars form the reserves.

Each turn, players now move their pieces over the board or place a piece from their reserves everywhere on the board. Object of the game is to either capture the opposing tesseract or capture all other "normal" pieces of the opponent.

The movements of the playing pieces different for every type. Interesting, that slide bars can capture normal pieces, but cannot be captured themselves.

name: Der Millionär
description:
The game is played within the box itself. The bottom has 30 slots to keep the available shares and 4 trays to save the money of the bank. The top cover can be left open and it indicates the current value and dividends for each title.

The game includes 5 shares numbered 1-5 in 6 different colors.

Players throw one 6-sided die and one color-die to determine which of the shares can be bought, pay dividends or maybe give special gratifications. If a 6 is thrown, the share of the thrown color is given a new value by an additional dice throw.

The game starts with 200.000 for each player and the one who collects 1 million first is the winner

name: Elo Moussaillon
description:
In this games players are maneuvering their fishing ship on a mobile board circular which emulate currents and obstacle. The object of the game is to catch and sell a variety of fish of different market value.

Clearly positioned as a family game (and designed by the members of a single family), this French micro-edition is also an educational game trying to provide some insights about sea and the coastal fishing industry.
mechanics: Area Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Benny Goodman Swings into a Game of Musical Information
description:
"Benny Goodman Swings into a Game of Musical Information" is a Benny-Goodman-endorsed game which includes an 8-note metal xylophone with a wooden mallet, which is used for a music-guessing portion of the game, similar to Name That Tune.

One player acts as a "Music Professor" (a sort of host for the game), while the other players are his students. The students are quizzed on their knowledge of popular songs and classical music. Challenges include straight question-and-answer trivia, guessing songs from their chorus, and guessing songs which the professor plays on the xylophone. The player with the highest score, based on number of correct answers, is the winner.

name: Earth Alert
description:
Object: to be the first player to successfully reach all three EarthAlert Recycle Centers and earn a Unit of Oxygen at the final Recycle Center.

There are three types of cards needed to move around the board:

Question and Answer, in which a player must answer a true/false or multiple choice environmental question.

Definitions, in which player must define a geographical or environmental word or location.

Roleplay, in which player must guess what subject is being acted out by two other players. Example: One player must play the role of a pregnant woman, the other player is a taxi cab. The answer is "birth."

Each time a recycle center is entered, a recycle card is drawn with hints and suggestions on how to save the environment.

To answer any card incorrectly is to lose a Unit of Oxygen. But in the end, there is always the "Last Gasp" opportunity.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Point to Point Movement, Role Playing

name: Tooty Frooty: the New Mr. Potato Head Game
description: Mr. Potato Head played Cootie style. Each player selects a plastic head (potato, cucumber, orange or carrot), then spins the large spinner to determine what (if any) piece is added to their character.

name: Victo
description: The "New All-American Party Thriller!" from 1942...Victo is a WWII era Bingo game with quotes from American war heroes and leaders replacing the usual I-24. Players are reminded on every card to "Buy U.S. War Bonds & Stamps."

name: Minnesota Minutiae
description: Minnesota Minutiae is a boxed deck of trivia cards, featuring the state of Minnesota. Categories include music, politics, sports, geography and history. No instructions or score-keeping bits are included, the cards may be designed as a replacement set for an existing trivia game.

name: Total Play Football
description:
From the website:

TOTAL PLAY FOOTBALL™ is a card game designed for non-stop action. Players able to recognize different Offensive card plays and make Defensive counter plays will certainly have the advantage. There is no turn for play in the Total Play Football Card Game. Any player can make a play for points or deny points at any time which adds even more fun and excitement to the game. For the love of the game called football and the advent of new technology, football can be played a myriad of ways. No one will feel excluded from playing Total Play Football™ because the game terminology does not require football lingo. All you need is the desire to win at an appealing and entertaining card game that is loads of fun for the whole family. The only way for you to know how well you will embrace the Total Play Football™ card game is to play it.

name: 4th Quarter TouchDown Football
description:
From the website:

4th Quarter Touchdown Football challenges your ability to work as teammates, while providing you with the entertainment of a board game. Set up as teams to challenge your opponents with fast action game play. By matching the game cards and moving down the field, your objective is to outscore your opponents before time runs out. Each player will lay their cards on the board and try to match, when a successful match is made the board is cleared and the attempt on an offensive advance is made for a second consecutive match. The yardage cards provided will move you forward for the quick score, or move you backward for loss yardages. But watch out for the turnovers, these cards could allow your opponents to score. Watch as the anticipation mounts as each passing card chooses the fate of your team and your record

Includes playing board, 64 playing cards, 40 home/away yardage cards, two game pieces, 100 score sheets, and a pencil.

name: The AAA Safe Driver Game
description:
From the insert:

The object of this game is to be the first player to land on each of the six blue Safe Driver Stars by exact roll of 1 or 2 dice while traveling clockwise around the gameboard. Player draws the Safe Driver Card from the deck on gameboard which matches the Safe Driver Star on which he has landed. First player to reach HOME with all six different Safe Driver Cards wins the game.

Parts list: 1 gameboard and box with rules platform and plastic tray; 14 Violation cards; 4 AAA Membership cards; 4 sets of 6 Safe Driver Cards; 2 dice; 4 playing pieces; 1 returnable market research card; and approximately $850 play money.

- - - - - - - -

The market research card (return address: Interstate Games, 35 Morrison St. Manchester, NH 03104) asks if you enjoyed playing the game, found the directions easy to follow; learned more about AAA services, etc. It also asks how many times you played it and with what ages of players (10-15, 15-20, 20-50, and over 50). Box says for ages 8-80.

Anyway, I wonder how many surveys were returned to them.

name: Geysers of Yellowstone
description:
Players are photographers trying to take the best pictures of geysers, hot springs, wildlife, hot springs, and scenery in Yellowstone National Park. Timing of geyser eruptions is card-driven. The board represents a portion of Yellowstone, and the game uses a point-to-point movement system.

The publisher's description:

There's nothing like the frenzied life of a photographer on a short deadline. You and your fellow shutterbugs have been sent to Yellowstone National Park with only one day to get all the pictures for a twelve-month calendar. At the end of the day, your publisher will pick the twelve best photos for the calendar. Your goal: get more pictures in the calendar than anyone else.

It won’t be easy. Should you gamble on the uncertain schedule of erupting geysers? Or stake out watering holes in hopes of getting a great shot of the wildlife? Grab your camera and get out on the road; you have until sundown to collect as many snapshots as you can. And don’t forget to take off your lens cap.

Geysers of Yellowstone is a quick-playing board game about the thrilling world of nature photography. Players move on a board that represents Yellowstone National Park, taking pictures of geysers, hot springs, wildlife, and scenery. Timing of geyser eruptions is card-driven. The player with the best photo portfolio at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Swords and Dice
description:
Well researched, light Ancients rules covering the Greek and Persian Wars, the campaign of Alexander the Great, and the Second Punic War.

Written for individually based miniatures in movement trays.
Each unit is rated for shooting, melee, morale and special abilities, and move and fight in strict formation. Fighting involves rolling lots of dice.

The rule set includes army lists and historical scenarios.

name: Mr. Muscle
description:
An interesting game that verges on being just a toy. There is a plastic muscle-man, with an empty barbell, and yellow plastic discs as weights. The game employs a winch system and a turn-crank, by which the players move the Mr. Muscle figure's arms to lift the barbell.

Theme: Weightlifting. Children's game.

name: The Horseless Carriage Race
description:
This very early game from McLoughlin Brothers of New York was produced just as automobiles came on to the scene as viable transportation. The map showed the U.S., southern Canada, and northern Mexico with major cities such as New York, New Orleans, Mexico City, Los Angeles and Quebec depicted.

In this game, players race across the country. The cars are moved by spinning a cardboard rondel.

The game was a simple spin and move game which featured spots on the board where one might lose a turn because of breakdowns or repairs.

name: Real-Action Baseball
description:
From the box cover: The game that's just like real baseball -- you actually make every play! Play fielders where you want! Send men after moving ball! Players field ball, run with it, throw to basemen who cover bags! You move batter, runners! Baseball know-how, strategy, luck! Fast-moving -- takes about 1/2 hour! Based on 2000 big league games! Scores just like in the majors! Sturdy board, 18 men, ball!

Basically, a spinner (1 to 6) is spun three times. The results of these spins determine the play -- a first spin "1" is a walk or a strikeout. Once the ball is in play and the location has been determined, the defensive player moves the fielders to the ball before arrows push the ball past. The offensive player moves the batter until the play is resolved.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Haus-Nummer
description: Players lay out 9 cards with numbers from 1-9. Each turn, a player throws 2 dice and turns over 2 cards depicting the numbers on the dice, or 1 card showing the sum of the 2 dice. The game is over after the fifth dice throw! The cards that could not be turned over are assembled to one number and the player with the lowest number is the winner.

name: Häst-Hopp
description:
Häst-Hopp is a children's game for ages 5 and up for 2-3 players. The title translates into Horse Jump.

You pick your favorite horse and compete in horse jumping. Draw tiles and build your courses side-by-side. Jump the bars with the help of the color-coded die. The fastest horse wins.

Game-play is entirely driven by chance in the shape of a stack of tiles and a die. The only skill involved is whether to use some rare free-jump tiles on an easy or a difficult obstacle.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Racing, Sports
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Sea Rats!
description:
As the rules put it "The object o' Sea Rats! is to be the last pirate afloat".

Each player starts with one ship, six cannonballs, and six crates of supplies used to repair damage. The ships are positioned on a sea map board that can be rolled up for storage. Each ship starts at a different port. Cargo can be gained or lost by moving to ports, fighting other ships, and bribing, extorting, or trading with other pirates.

Dice rolls determine which port you can stock up at next, how much cargo you load, how far you move, and whether your cannonballs hit the ship you aim at. You may also attempt to take "The Treasure" which may be used as a bribe that can't be refused, to buy an extra die for movement, or to buy an extra cargo die with the ability to overload your ship. Possession, not expenditure, of the treasure allows docking at any port.

A ship hit with more cannonballs than it has crates sinks to Davy Jones' Locker, and the losing captain is out of the game. The victorious captain may expend his own crates to keep the ship from sinking and control an additional ship himself, or allow the previous captain to stay on in a subservient role and continue to play the ship if "he/she swears an oath o' allegiance". This can be used in many cases to keep all players involved in the game to the end.

From the Publisher:

AVAST YE!
Welcome te Sea Rats!™, the most excitin' pirate board game this side o' the Ivory Coast. Where old salts and landlubbers alike sail ships on the high seas, battle with their enemies, stock up at ports o' call, an', best of all, steal The Treasure—Arrrghhh!

Send yer buddies down te Davy Jones' Locker. Capture "the prize" an' build up a fleet o' ships! Bribe yer enemies te escape hostile fire—whatever it takes te be the last pirate afloat an' win the game! It's easy te learn an' totally wicked fun to play!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tier Combino
description:
Tier-Combino is a memory variant with groups of 3 cards instead of 2 cards, but a player can reveal only 2 cards per turn as in normal memory.

The hexagon shaped cards show 15 such groups of 3 cards.

name: Gedrängel
description:
Gedrängel (=scramble) is a funny Malefiz variant, where all players can move with all playing pieces!

Opposite to Malefiz is the winning option: you must bring your 4 playing pieces AND 3 tokens of different colors to their target spaces to be the winner.

name: Dhaemon
description:
Played in Mauritania and Western Sahara, Dhaemon is a game similar to checkers and/or Seega. It is played on a 9x9 grid, usually made out of piled sand, and the opposing game pieces are frequently represented by short sticks on one side and dessicated camel droppings on the other. It has been featured in the travel book "Sahara" by Michael Palin, and the BBC TV series of the same name [2002].

It is possible that this is the game referred to as Srand or Dhamet by Lhôte.

name: Derby Downs
description: A horse-racing game similar to They're at the Post. This game uses a single double-sided record to simulate 10 different races with 10 different horses -- the needle is placed on the record and one of five tracks is available for the race. The races are called by Chick Anderson (then official announcer of the Kentucky Derby). Bets are paid off based on a set of official betting cards.

name: Rolling Dice Downs
description: This self-published game uses a system similar to that in Win, Place & Show to simulate a series of horse races. Each player is required to bet within certain minimums and maximums, with only the winning horse for each race paying out. The winner is the player with the most cash at the end of the series of races (usually six or nine).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Burlington International Cross Country Horse Game
description: Players maneuver their horses through a cross-country course while trying to avoid penalties. Players must be a little lucky as well as knowledgeable as they must answer questions to avoid penalties.

name: Rösselsprung
description:
This is an interesting game about the knight move in chess.

The board has the shape of a cross. The middle of the cross is the common zone, while the outer parts of the board are reserved as starting/ending section for specific players.

Each player starts with 7 knights/horses and must try to bring them to the opposite side of the board. However, there are some instructions for that: all knights must cross the starting section before the can cross the common section and finally enter the ending section.

Movements are determined with the roll of a die, where the thrown number is the number of (chess-)knight moves that 1 single knight must perform in one turn. Starting and ending sections are save, but captures are allowed in the common zone.

name: Der Cylinderhut
description: This is a late 19th century roll and move parlor game similar to "snakes and ladders" with money. The primary differences between the two seem largely to be the action spaces. Where as "snakes and ladders" sends a player back a number of spaces in der Cylinderhut players pay penalties. The winner is the first to the end, and he collects the cash.

name: Perlenkönig
description:
"Pearl King"

The game contents are:
7 board tiles (one side display "water", the other "beach")
80 oysters counters (40 have pearls)
12 pearl cards (1 with a little crown)
1 special die (4 sides: oyster, 1 side: moon, 1 side: oyster with arrows)

The players try to find pearls on the beach. The 7 board tiles are laid out in such a way, that 5 tiles show water (the sea), 2 tiles show sand (the beach). Each beach tile carries six face down oysters. It is low-tide and the waterline will recede (= a tile is turned over) whenever a moon symbol is rolled. New oysters are put on the new beach tile. After all tiles have become beach, it is high-tide: each moon symbol rolled means that a tile has to be turned over again. When all tiles have become water, the game is over.
A player rolling an oyster may look under an oyster: if it is empty, he puts it back, if there's a pearl, he takes the counter. If he rolls the arrow symbol, he also looks for an oyster but puts an additional oyster on one of the beach tiles. The player with the most pearls gets a pearl card. The player who first has three pearl cards after consecutive plays, receives the crown card and may call himself the pearl king.

name: Competitive Compass Game
description: This game is a gem used in the Boy Scouts to teach orienteering - this skill of using a compass to navigate. You set up 10 stakes spaced at 10 foot intervals, there are several cards that you give to each team and it has a direction and distance of 3 legs. Each team starts at one stake and navigates to the final stake. You get points for how close you are. the length of the game depends mostly on how flat the terrain is. It could take only 60 minutes or even two hours, but most seem to take about 90 minutes from what I remember.
mechanics: Line Drawing, Point to Point Movement

name: Neues Lustiges Rad-Fahr Spiel
description:
This is a facsimile of a Ravensburger game from 1904 published to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Vedes toy trade group in 1979.

The game is a simple, roll-and-move bicycle race with one board with three different racetracks. Six cardboard bikers on wooden bases are provided but the rule sheet states that the number of players is not limited; there are two dice, one D6, one with special letters on it; a little tin plate; extremely cute tin money in a small pouch and two embossed cardboard medals.

The rules encourage the players to play all three tracks in succession - though it is also possible to play only a single track. Play goes counter-clockwise(!). All spaces on the board are numbered, special events on some of these numbers are explained in the rules ("put money on the plate", "collect money from the other players", "go back some spaces" and so on).

name: Post Office Game
description:
An early Parker Brothers game from 1898. Post Office Game revolves around the dense cityscape and urban hustle and bustle of lower Manhattan at or near the turn of the century. Players travel along a game board from streets on Manhattan's Southern tip ( South Ferry, Aquarium, Wall Street and the Wall Street Ferry all the way North to 23rd Street). Places to visit include American Line Terminal, Fall River Line, The Tombs, Brooklyn Bridge, the Post Office & Bowling Green.
Famous New York Streets from the time are used to move about; Broadway, West Broadway, Fulton, Pearl, Canal, East Houston, The Bowery, Division and Furman Streets.
Delivering mail to particular places in the city was the goal of the game. First person to complete their assigned deliveries won the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jerome Park Steeplechase Game
description:
Jerome Park Steeplechase is a very early game from McLoughlin Brothers and was produced circa 1885. Jerome Park itself was located in the Fordham section of the Bronx and staged races from the late 1860's to around 1890.

The game; Players decide before the game begins what wagers the game would be played for. Each horse would cost a player some pre-determined amount of money. After casting lots with dice to decide what order each player would move in, each player would roll the dice and then place their horse on the number rolled. Each player could take several horses but the cost to have more than one would increase. Having a second horse in the race would cost the owner one and a half times the fee for the initial horse.

There were bad spots on the board. The #10 spot forced a player to lose his next turn and spots 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80 and 90 forced players to go back to their previous position on the board. Spots 16,33,48 & 68 were places where hedges were located. If one rolled a number that would place ones horse on any of these numbers one had to pay a fine of the entrance fee for the horse and then return to the place one started this turn from. As one gets closer to the finish line the number of dice one throws decreases so players in the rear have an opportunity to catch up. First player to reach spot number 100 wins and collects whatever wagers were involved in the game. If you rolled more than 100 then, on subsequent turns, you would roll the die and go backwards or forward whatever number you rolled until you reached the 100 square exactly.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Game of Flags
description:
Collect set of flags by calling out missing cards. If opponent has the card, he has to surrender it to the caller. Make sets of four to earn points. A special "crown card" can be used to substitute a missing card. The winner of the game is the player having the most sets at the end.

As the game is pretty old (1896 on the box) some flags have changed since then.

Seemingly a variant of The Game of Authors or Happy Families
publishers: Cincinnati Game Co., Fireside Game Co., McLoughlin Brothers, The United States Playing Card Company

name: Trio
description:
In this game, players place bets on the outcome of 3 horse races. Winner is the richest player after the 3 races.

The races themselves are done with the roll of 2 dice: 1 die determines, which horses can move, the other die gives the number of spaces, that can be moved. Since there are only 5 horses in the game (numbered from 1-5), a roll of six can be used as joker and enables to move a horse of your choice.

name: New Testament Game
description:
Part of a series of games published at the end of the Victorian era, the New Testament Game (No. 1124) follows the same formulaic gameplay of the other Cincinnati Game Co. games (including the Game of Flowers, No. 1126, also published in 1899, and the the Game of Shakespeare, published in 1900).

In the New Testament Game, cards depict scenes from the life of Christ from birth through resurrection, ascensions and omnipotence, As in other Cincinnati Games Co. games, the cards are given a letter and number (A-M and 1-4, arranged as A1, A2, etc.). Players attempt to complete a "book" of cards (all four numbered cards of a given letter) by collecting the necessary cards from opponents.

Simple games are played like Go Fish where a player asks for a card by letter and number from any other player.

Players can play more challenging games using biblical quotes at the bottom of each card. Before a card is surrendered, the quote is read and the active player must state the book of the bible from which the quotation comes.

There are also topics at the bottom of the cards allowing for play similar to the Game of Authors.

The cards feature black and white illustrations by world renowned artists (and even some world renowned paintings) such as DaVinci's Last Supper and Hoffmann's ubiquitous version of Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane.

Also includes works by Doré, Bougereau, Plockhorst, Portaels, Le Rolle, Muller, Godall, Benz, Mengelberg, Zimmermann, Cornicelius, Richter, Kirkbuck, Murillo, Rubens, Grieger, Munkacsy, Herriach, Raphael, Reni, Schonherr, and Coletti.
publishers: Cincinnati Game Co., Fireside Game Co.

name: Crazy Hospital
description:
Some Professors have decided to earn more money, more fame and more ....of everything.
They open up their own hospital, hire personal let the doctors take some additional training and then heal all the patients that are available. That´s the theory.
In practice it´s a bit different. If another player has personal that fell in love with some of yours, it´s possible to lose an important part of your staff and even some rich patients. You may use a little bit of sabotage and when your doctor can heal a illness and no other can, where would the patient go ??
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: XQ Card Game
description: XQ is a family-oriented card game to be played between parents and young kids of 5 or older. The object of the game is to collect happy expressions from father, mother, brother, and sister. The game helps release stress any one player may suffer throughout the day and to bring a smile back to his or her face. There are only pictures, no words. The die is color coded as opposed to numbered.

name: In The Picture: The Kids' Art Game
description:
"A picture is missing from the Painting Gallery! Can you identify the picture that belongs in the empty frame? Search the museum for clues to solve this mystery. The first player to take the missing picture to the Painting Gallery wins the game."

Sort of an Art Gallery clue game, with rooms on a board: Classroom, Cafe, Information Desk, Sculpture Galleries I and II, Library, North American Gallery, Auditorium, Gift Shop and Painting Gallery.

Go to the rooms, answer the clues, find the missing painting.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Roanoke The Star City Game
description: This is a version of Monopoly put out in Roanoke, VA. It features businesses local to the area, such as Imagination Station, Dominion Bankshares Mortgage,and Leggett.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Flusspiraten
description:
Each player has 9 tiles in 5 different shapes, showing parts of a river with funny drawings.

The die shows the 5 shapes plus a star, which is used as joker. The player throw the die and must try to place the tile with the thrown shape on the board - on either end of the river. If a player does not have a tile with the thrown shape anymore, he must take back as many tiles from the river until he gets that tile again.

Winner is the player who gets rid of all his tiles first, but this can take quite a while, because taking back tiles is very usual.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Lords & Levies
description:
From the website http://www.tsoa.be/html/titelblad_uk_medieval.html

DESIGNER'S NOTES:
This is the fourth set in my card driven wargame rules, and although still loosely inspired by the Battle Cry & Memoir '44 games by Richard Borg, the game no longer has a battlefield divided in 3 sections. Battlefield sections are great for ACW and WWII, but medieval battles need a different approach. The left-center-right wing Battle Cry/Memoir '44 principle has here been replaced by color-coding the units red, green and blue (activated by cards of the same color) thus enabling the players to concentrate their units anywhere on the battlefield if they wish so. Also, quality of armor plays a prominent role in medieval battles. Therefore the symbols on the dice are no longer representing infantry - cavalry - artillery but rather the quality of the armor of the troops targeted, whereby troops with heavier armor stand less of a chance of being killed than soldiers with lighter or no armor (see rules).

name: "Oy Vey"
description:
"OY VEY" Game Where You Become a Jewish Mother

Ages 12 and up.

Each player becomes a Jewish mother with a family of two sons and two daughters.

The object of the game is to get both sons to become doctors and both daughters to marry doctors.

Contents: game board; naches cards for good luck; tsouris cards for bad luck; color coded discs and pawns; 2 dice and instructions.

4 complete original games available from the creator.
Contact Rich at solarplexusrich@yahoo.com

name: Walter Johnson Base Ball Game
description:
An early baseball game featuring Washington Senator Walter "Big Train" Johnson. Interaction is at a low point here, as defense is played on offense. The player who is at bat, spins a teetotum with various play results engraved on each side. Whatever the result on the spinner, is the result on the field. Play nine innings and rack up the score.

The teetotum has 20 sides, with the following results:

1 Home Run, 1 Triple, 1 Double, 2 Singles, 3 Infield Outs, 2 Fly Outs, 1 Sacrifice Fly Out, 1 Double Play, 1 Error, 1 Stolen Base, 3 Balls, 2 Strikes and 1 Foul.

Walter Johnson (1887 - 1946)

name: Battlecards: World Conflict – Six Days of Destiny
description:
(from publisher)
The next in DGA's critically acclaimed Battlecards: World Conflict series, Six Days of Destiny captures all the action, political maneuvers, and intrigue of the 1967 Arab-Israeli conflict. While little is taught in today's classrooms about the war, this modern day David and Goliath story is still forming the world we live in.

In May of 1967, after a 10 year buildup of Arab military force in Sinai, Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser amassed the armies of Egypt, Syria, and Jordan on the borders of Israel. By the end of that same month, Egypt engaged in the first official military action of the 6-day war by declaring a naval blockade against the nation of Israel. After concentrating an enormous Arab amphibious assault force just 17km from the coast of Israel, Nasser ominously proclaimed, "The armies of Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon are poised on the borders of Israel...to face the challenge, while standing behind us are the armies of Iraq, Algeria, Kuwait, Sudan and the whole Arab nation. This act will astound the world. Today they will know that the Arabs are arranged for battle, the critical hour has arrived. We have reached the stage of serious action and not declarations."

Echoing these sentiments, the Iraqi President Abdur Rahman Aref boldly declared, "The existence of Israel is an error which must be rectified. This is our opportunity to wipe out the ignominy that has been with us since 1948. Our goal is clear: 'to wipe Israel off the map'."

But Israel refused to go quietly into the night. On June 5th, 1967, the Israeli Air Force launched a pre-emptive attack against Egyptian airfields full of bombers, poised for the assault. One of the shortest, yet most influential wars since World War II had begun in earnest, and almost 40 years later, the world is still sorting out the aftermath.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Secret Unit Deployment

name: The Test Driver Game
description: Test Driver at the Chrysler Corporation Proving Grounds is a simple roll and move game that features a long oval track. Particular spaces on the track cause things to happen to your race car. Object of the game is to get around the track as fast as possible
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Thinking for Action
description: Edward De Bono's "Super Mind Pack" contains the book 'Thinking for Action and many pieces for playing 30 games, each especially created to a different thinking strategy. The ability to think creatively is a vital skill, but the ability to focus your thoughts and apply them in a practical way is just as important. This product is much more geared towards utilizing playing games to expand ones thinking for getting things done, than its sister product Mind Pack. The package comes with dice, playing chits, several pages of playing tokens, and 11 playing boards.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Economic, Educational, Math, Maze, Memory, Negotiation, Party Game, Political, Puzzle, Word Game
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Commodity Speculation, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Memory, Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Amazing Africa: A Cultural Adventure
description: A part of the Fast Track Learning game series, the card game is designed to help children learn important facts about the history, culture, people and geography of Africa. Each card features a question and an answer to another question found on a matching card; players take turns asking other players for cards that answer their questions (similar to Go Fish). The player with the most matches at the end of the game wins.

name: Environment
description:
From the box:

ENVIRONMENT is a game of skill and fun with the accent on learning and awareness of the World around you. It will leave you thinking!

Playing the game involves spinning the Dolphin to select a colour destination and question. Questions are based on the World's environment as well as Geographical and Historical subjects testing your General Knowledge.

By moving the counters (carriers) clockwise on the Latitudes you make your way to the top of the World to collect a subject, returning anti-clockwise with it to home base. During play there is a tactical element along with a lighter side of the game.

ENVIRONMENT is played by 2 to 6 players individually or as teams with as many as you wish on each side aged from 15 to adult.

name: Mystique
description:
From the box:

"Know you all a comic's chin? A stately nose, a golfer's grin? A President's brow, a pop star's cheek? The name?....alas.... the game's Mystique."

MYSTIQUE is a new and exciting game for all the family. A numbered casket contains 75 famous faces from the past and present.

As the face is gradually revealed the players attempt to identify the personality whilst collecting simple information cards.

A simple and entertaining game which can be played anywhere, anytime by everyone!

---

In essence a simple deduction game where players try and identify a celebrity from parts of a (sketched) picture. Help is provided in the form of FAX cards that provide information on gender, whether they are alive or dead, where they come from, and for which reason they may be famous (pop music, sport, cinema, television, public life, the arts).

A somewhat complex scoring system is used to determine the winner of each round, and ultimately the winner of the game.
publishers: Henry Zabel Limited, Pharos Games Ltd.

name: Whampoo
description:
A game that was found traditionally in Newfoundland but also found in Quebec (slight variant) known as Tock.

The Board is an outside track with a starting hold area and a final "home" area.

Players work in teams using cards to either move their own pieces forward or to take actions on other players.

Winners are the first team to get all their pieces into the appropriate home area

name: Oldtimer Rally
description:
Oldtimer Rally is played with a deck of 68 cards and 2 dice:

12 oldtimers (2 of each model/color)
1 start
1 finish

54 road cards with
- 38 normal roads
- 16 obstacles (4 x 4 different)

The 54 road cards are put on the table face down to form the race course. Each player gets 2 oldtimers of the same color. Each turn, a player must move both of his oldtimers by throwing the 2 dice. The card where a car stops is turned over. If it's an obstacle, the player must follow the rules for that obstacle and the card is turned back again. If a car would land on a card with another oldtimer, the moving car is going off the course and must begin the race at the start again.

Winner of the game is the player, whose 2 oldtimers reach the finish line first.

name: The Road to War: Europe 1936
description:
'The Road to War: Europe 1936' seeks to portray the geopolitical turmoil on the eve of World War II. Players assume the role of European statesmen seeking to outclass their geopolitical rivals and attain a position of predominance.

The game is based upon Allan B. Calhamer's classic Diplomacy. However, its treatment of minor powers is strikingly different as these have their own military units. Players secretly bid influence points in order to obtain the support of these lesser powers.

The game closely resembles the designer's previous geopolitical game Locarno: Europe 1926, though various changes were made in order to take account of the spectacular rise of the USSR as an industrial power since 1926 and the looming Spanish Civil War - pitting the foreign-backed Nationalist and Republican factions against each other.

The rules and maps are provided further below.

Re-implements:

Locarno: Europe 1926
categories: Bluffing, Negotiation, Political, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Area Movement, Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection, Voting

name: Scoreboard Cricket
description: Similar to card cricket where two cards are drawn - one from each pack and the score and play is determined by the corresponding square on the board. Scores are then entered in the score pad. When an uneven score is shown the second batsmen faces the bowler, if even runs are scored the same batter picks up the next card. When a batter goes out the new batter faces the bowler ... there are a few other rules but not too complicated.

name: Kick Back
description:
The game consists of a narrow plastic board about 20" long with a plastic 'kicking mule' in a "corral" at either end. A small plastic ball is connected to a length of string which originates from the center of the board. A scoring track runs along each edge of the board between the corrals.

Players take turns placing the ball on the hind feet of their kicking mule and attempt to kick the ball into the opposite corral by flicking down the front legs of their mule. A point is scored each time the ball comes to rest in their opponent's corral and the relevant marker is advanced one notch along the scoring track.

The first player to reach the end of their scoring track (19 successful kicks) is the winner.

name: TRY Time
description:
TRY Time is a game that simulates a rugby league season or a rugby cup competition.

The first part of the game involves building up your team and backroom staff whilst staying within budget, fast paced, dynamic! A season or cup competition is complete in just 20 minutes.

If players choose to progress to a cup final or the play offs after the regular season or cup opening rounds are complete then the teams built during part 1 of TRY Time or alternatively fantasy / real teams of the players choice are used to compete in a head to head matches using the patented TRY Time game slider and ball. Head to Head matches take an additional 20 minutes per game.

name: The Solar System Game
description:
In this unprecedented year of space exploration, students and adults alike will benefit from the in-depth information packed into this exciting game.
Players learn more than 200 interesting facts about the solar system as they advance through three stages of play from the novice to master level.
Players collect card sets consisting of "object" and "interesting facts" cards.
The object of the game is to collect as many card sets as possible.
Visually stunning, this game features actual NASA photography.
Features historical facts and current discoveries.

In a classroom or family setting, players use basic knowledge to move around the board while they build their knowledge of current and historic facts about the Solar System. 'Interesting Facts' cards are collected and read aloud to the group, revealing more in-depth information.

Content covers the universe, planets, astronomers, the Sun, the moons, and asteroids. Fun facts include the fastest, hottest, largest, and coldest planets; planet with the highest mountain; the planet that would float in water, and hundreds more!

Glossary and definitions include. Teach new vocabulary.

Open-ended play! The player to collect the largest number of card sets within any given time period wins.

name: Integer Chess
description:
The coordinate plane is the 'playground' of algebra, the arena where algebraic concepts are displayed graphically. Integer Chess, helps grades 3 - 7 students understand and develop proficiency in skills involving graphing, making vector-like moves, etc. on the coordinate plane! Students will be prepared to use this vital algebraic tool will before formal study of algebra begins.
Integer Chess, features three Power Learning integer games played on the coordinate plane! Each game offers simple to complex strategies, challenging novices and masters alike! Understanding of vital algebraic concepts develops through play.

Locations & Moves familiarizes students with graphing points and making vector-like-moves.

Integer Addends & Sums challenges students to find strategic locations using vector-like sums.

Integer Products & Factors challenges students to find strategic locations using vector-like products.

Each move in these Power Learning games requires students to examine multiple options, thereby intensifying practice.

Contents:

Instructions
Integer Chess Game Board
Spinner
4 Sets of Pawns
publishers: Creative Teaching Associates, Learning Advantage, Wiebe, Carlson & Associates

name: Roll & Write Word Game
description:
Children build and sound out hundreds of words—as they combine beginning sounds on the dice with ending sounds on our game board! The 18 3/4" game board comes with 9 color-coded foam dice, 4 write & wipe scorecards, 4 markers and a handy word list…plus instructions for multiple levels of play. For 2-4 players.

Targets standards in these areas:
• Initial phoneme substitution
• Identifying words with common endings
• Research & reference skills

name: Roll and Read Word Family Game
description:
Kids roll the dice, start the timer…then combine onsets and rimes to build tons of words before time is up! Game highlights 24 different word families, and includes 4 write & wipe scorecards, markers, dice and more. 1-4 players.

Targets standards in these areas:
• Identifying spelling patterns
• Identifying onsets and rimes
• Decoding & vocabulary

name: First Learning Games of Animals
description: Contains 20 learning games for young children. Includes Pushout animal picture boards, spinner, animal picnic game board, mother and baby animal cards, animal dominoes and animal markers.
mechanics: Area Movement, Memory, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chrysalis: Borne of the Supernature
description:
Create a character of your own choosing, whether this is entirely NEW, or someone more familiar for yourself and any others, from yet some well known genre.

The full set includes over 300 CARDS of which these will contain 5 Basic categories for: Sorcery; Mutagen; Psionic; Power; & Weaponry.

You'll begin with some starting core abilities, and obtain additional assets, maneuvers, etc. or increase your current kinds through encounters with others. This will even be happening while you are engaged with one another, as Combat develops yourself further during gameplay.

These feature the artwork from the likes for: Jill Thompson; Simon Bisley; Walt Simonson; & Dave Gibbons. Depending upon the actual Character that you wish to emulate from this all, then that will also shape your aptitudes for whenever you go up against yet someone else's unique and most likely favorite ones.

You can explore upon classic Good VS Bad guys, or pit even those against each other in some manner for a "showdown" sort of gaming experiences.

name: Das Känguruhspiel
description:
This is a game for ages 6 and up. The box itself is the board and contains 1 die and 50 wooden pins.

The wooden board can be folded into a box to contain the die and the pins.

On top of the board there are 6 numbered borings. The pins fit in these borings. The boring with number 6 leads directly to the inner part of the board. If you put a pin here it goes down directly.

The aim of the game is to get rid of your pins as fast a possible. The pins are distributed amongst the players.

On your turn you roll the die and you put a pin in the boring with the number you have rolled, if that is still free. You can choose to roll again or you can pass and give the turn to the next player.

If the rolled boring is already occupied, you have to take the pin and your turn ends.

The game ends as soon as one of the players got rid of all his pins.

name: Cassa
description:
This is a game for ages 6 and up. The box contains 1 potter's wheel and 100 coins.

The wheel contains 2 circles, and is therefore always showing two results. The outermost circle contains 4 letters (G, N, A and E), the inner circle contains the numbers 1 to 6.

The coins are distributed amongst the players.

On your turn, you name one of the other players and you turn the wheel. If the wheel stops on the "E", you have to pay the indicated amount of coins to the Bank. Stopping on the "A", means you get all the coins present in the Bank.
Does the wheel stop on "G", the player you have named has to pay you the indicated amount of coins. While stopping on "N" means that you have to pay the indicated amount to the player you have named.

The game ends if one of the players runs out of coins. The winner is the one with the most coins remaining.

name: The Game of Time
description: The Game of Time was first produced in 1913 by the National Game Company in Australia. Board visuals include circular tracks of concentric rings and stylistically period lithographics of the seasons with gilt surrounds. Players spin a tee-totum to move their piece around the rings beginning on 1 minute. After completing 60 minutes by exact spin a player can progress to the inner ring of 24 hours, then a further inner ring of 7 days and weeks, then the 12 months and finally to home which is one year. The board promotes that it is "an instructive game for any number of players" hinting that the game aims to be educational on time and the seasons.

name: 10 Brettspiele
description:
This book contains the following 10 games from Hajo Bücken:

- Aram
- Cross Card (Poker on a board)
- Eisbärenspiel (co-operative)
- Feigling (or Kamikaze)
- Gamba-i-o (3 games in one: Gamba, Gambi, Gambo)
- Guck gut
- Tag und Nacht (co-operative)
- Team (or Stürzt den Diktator)
- Trigo
- Queen (or Wabenspiel)

The book gives the complete rules to every game as well as detailed instructions on how to create the numerous boards and playing aids.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Animals, Book, Card Game
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Tile Placement

name: Evil Ted
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Horror has come to the happy town of Cotton Falls! The peaceful teddy bears have become... zombears! A few lucky survivors have barricaded themselves in the remaining buildings. Can they escape from... the Evil Ted?

In Evil Ted, a twistedly cute take on the zombie genre, you'll need to break out of your base, find a vehicle, and escape from the hordes. Along the way, you'll find companions to help you survive the onslaught, and you'll collect equipment to defend yourself against the ravenous zombears - and from your companions, when they become undead! Be the first to flee safely from the hungry hordes!

name: The KnowHow Book of Action Games
description: This book is mostly devoted to making toys from household objects, but includes boards and rules for several new board games: There and Back, Matchmake, Hop Over, Cops and Robbers, Floor War, Space War. ISBN 0860200183 (hard bound version: the paperback version (ISBN 0590119303) seems to omit some games).
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Ed. Plesa, Scholastic Entertainment Inc., Usborne

name: Grand Total
description:
Grand Total is "Mathematical Equation Scrabble." Players place number and symbol tiles in a line to form an equation, scoring points for the number they use.

The board is large (18" square), colorful, and well-designed. It is ruled off in 1" squares, with numbers from 0 to 9 printed in about 10% of the squares. The tiles are cardboard counters of decent thickness - the numbers are red and the symbols (+, -, and =) yellow.

Players mix up the tiles, then draw seven numbers and three signs. In turn, each player places tiles on the board to make a "legal" equation, using at least one tile already on the board, crossword-style. Typical Scrabble rules are used regarding challenges and redraws. Player score the sum of the numbers they used, disregarding the results of the equation they formed. If a tile is placed on a space bearing the same number, it's double score.

A surprising rule is that a player may remove the equal sign from an equation on the board and replace it with a plus or minus if they can form a new equation that way. The removed "=" is reused further down the new equation.

Game meant for 2nd/3rd Grade and up.

name: Glückskäfer
description: A children's game, consisting of a tower, 4 ramps, 4 bugs and metal balls. Every player tries to maneuver his bug into the tower by shooting the balls against the tower. When the tower is hit, the bug moves upwards. All players play simultaneously. When a bug falls into the tower, this player wins.
publishers: Action Games and Toys Ltd, Bienengräber

name: Encounter at Hanover
description:
Encounter at Hanover is a promotional game for the town of Hanover, Pennsylvania, sponsored by the Hanover General Hospital Auxiliary.

Hanover is mostly famous for being the site of an American Civil War battle in the Gettysburg campaign. While the name of the game (the same as a book on the battle) and the box cover (which shows ACW soldiers) suggest a wargame of some kind, the game is in fact similar to Monopoly.

As in Monopoly players move around the board buying properties and improving them. Here the properties are local Hanover business and the improvements are franchises instead of houses . The rules are similar to Monopoly's with some exceptions, the main one being that ownership of a group is not required for development, but owning three properties in a row triples rent on them.

name: Kan Zen
description:
From the bottom of the box:

Kan Zen: the perfect word game

A GAME AND A WORLD:

KAN ZEN (tm) is more than a game. It is a world. In that world there is a place for everyone, and fun for everyone. There is also a place for all of the words on earth - those in your own language, those in foreign languages, ordinary words, and words that are the names of persons or places - if the letters of an alphabet can be used to spell them.

The game can be as easy, or as difficult, as the players choose to make it - among yourselves you agree on the kind of words that are to be used. The playing time can be readily adjusted to suit your convenience.

Above all, KAN ZEN is a world for those who let their imagination soar, discovering how much enjoyment they can have with a game that permits almost infinite variation.

KAN ZEN AT A GLANCE:

The board is a circular track, on which a step is taken for each letter of a word played. Letters drawn at random at the beginning of each move must be included in the words that you use. UP-TURNS, where the TALLY (letter count) is added to your score, alternate with DOWN-TURNS, where the TALLY is subtracted, unless evasive action is taken. The "perfect" words are those whose TALLIES enable you to move to sectors of the circle where the best advantage can be taken on multiple scoring opportunities on UP-TURNS or where losses can be avoided or minimized on DOWN-TURNS. The winner is the player with the highest net accumulative TALLY at the end of the game.

HOW MANY CAN PLAY?

Two, three or four sides can play the highly competitive versions of the The Perfect Word Game - as individuals, partners or teams.

The game can also be played "solo". Those who love words, or who find pleasure in drawing on a well-stocked memory of names of persons and places, may well consider KAN ZEN the best solitaire game in the world.

name: Hi Score
description:
"Hi Score" was published in the German magazine Pöppel-Revue 5/86 as "Spiel im Heft".

The board has 6x6 spaces and both players have 18 stones, numbered from 1-18 on the front side and empty on the back side.

The game begins with an empty board. Each turn, a player places a stone on the board on the same row or column the last stone has been placed. Stones can not be moved to other spaces, but they are (must be) flipped over, if the sum of own stones in a row or column is higher than the sum of the opposing stones.

The game ends, when a player can not place a stone on the board. To determine the winner, the numbers on the not yet played stones are subtracted from the total on the stones on the board. The higher total wins.

name: Oförberedd
description:
Oförberedd ("unprepared") is a Swedish trivia game, but not quite like most trivia games.

The object of the game is to get through high school, get a doctorate, and finally win by becoming a professor.

When a player is still a student, his examiner (the next player) draws a card and reads a subject from that. The subject is something like "Name a city by the river ....". The examiner reads the question and fills in the blank with something of his own choosing. If the student can answer, he gets a diploma in that subject (there are four different subjects). If the student can't answer, the examiner must answer the question. If he can't, he gets a warning. Otherwise, the student gets the warning. The rest of the players are arbiters in the case of disputes as to what is the correct answer to a question.

After collecting three diplomas, the player is finished with high school and can now start working on his doctorate. To achieve that, he must get a diploma in each of the four subjects. Once he has that, he must also hold a lecture. To get the subject of his lecture, the player arranges his diplomas in a certain order and reads the sentence that this creates (if he has more than one diploma in a subject he may choose which one to use). This will result in a subject like "The bad influence / of movies / upon art / in troubled times." The student must now keep a two-minute lecture on this subject. If there are no obvious errors in his lecture, he gets his doctorate. To become a professor, the doctor must get another diploma in each subject and hold another lecture over a given subject.

Contents:
- 48 student question cards
- 16 doctor question cards
- 12 warning cards
- 64 diplomas
- 6 "finished high school" counters (student's cap)
- 6 "become a doctor" counters (doctor's hat)
- 1 "become a professor" counter (laurel)
- Rules booklet
- Booklet with explanations of questions
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Storytelling, Voting

name: SNAFU
description:
The board for SNAFU (which here is supposedly "Situation Normal All Filled Up" - sure) consists of 100 squares in 5 colors - red, blue, green, and yellow, all of which are assigned to the players, plus pink. Each player or team (the 4-player game is for teams) takes a color of chips, white or black.

On a turn a player spins a spinner which produces a result from 0-5 in one of the board colors or white. If the color is pink or a friendly color, the player places markers in the number of spaces shown. If an opposing color, the player may choose to place the opposing markers on the board. If white, the player takes opposing markers off the board.

The game ends when one of four possible conditions are met - one team controls the main diagonal of the board, one team controls all squares of their colors, etc. None of these conditions automatically win the game, but some add points to the team's score.

name: Monstern! Brettspiel
description:
Game description by the publisher:
"A game by ASSASSIN, in co-production with Lutz Leischner.
A nice boardgame with tin miniatures, which should not be taken too seriously. We just call it Monstern!"

The game includes several nice tin miniatures, a gameboard and several dice.

name: Casey Jones Game Box
description: The Casey Jones Game Box contains three games: Blow the Whistle, Capital Run, and Freight Train. All games are played with a single die, and (at most) 20 train cars. Blow the Whistle is a simple race game for two players, playable by children as young as three-years-old. Players roll and move, with the requirement that they make horn sounds at certain points in the game. The first player to reach the finish line wins. Capital Run is a game for older children, with up to four players. This game also has a roll-and-move mechanic, and players must successfully name state capitals in order to earn a turn, with the object to cross the country on a preset path. Freight train is light but nontrivial game for two players, requiring players to assemble a set of different types of trains. These trains (coal tender, box car, flat car, cattle car) begin the game on preset spaces, and players must roll around the board and assemble their set. There are several opportunities for decisions.
categories: Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trains

name: Davy Crockett Adventures
description:
Walt Disney's Davy Crockett Adventures, basically each player tries to collect all four Davy Crockett adventure cards onto his playing rack.
These consist of: 'Davy Grins the Bear' , 'Davy Fights Redstick' ,'Davy Goes to Congress' , and 'Davy at the Alamo'
This collection process involves the spinning of a spinner (which is a picture of Fess Parker as Davy Crockett holding a rifle) when the rifle points to one of the adventure cards it is yours. The only catch is that you have to collect the adventures in the order that they happened.
categories: Adventure, American West, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Giant Steps
description:
The Object is to be the first player to cross the street on the blue border "GIANT STEPS" and then back again to his colored "Start" space.
Draw cards, do what they say in order to move. The game requires good manners to move, you must say "May I" of the person on the right, if you don't you lose your turn.

name: Underground Railroad Perilous Journey to Freedom
description: Object: To become the first player to reach freedom in Canada, by answering trivia questions and avoiding the "Patroller" pawn who gets closer for each incorrect answer. Dice are used for only the first turn, after that movement is decided by the trivia cards. The papers inside the box state that there were only 1000 of this game produced.

name: Waifs and Strays
description:
These character/story based trading cards were made for spooky girls who have no interest in those angry little characters the boys seem to gravitate to. 16 orphaned girls each have their own unique story of how they became orphaned; each lost an object during their difficult time, developed a magic spell and adopted a pet monster. The girls are all somehow later involved in another tragic death. The cards have point values and there is a game that can be played regardless of how many cards have collected. 8 evil puppet cards are included in the full set.

More information:
http://www.therss.com/store/product_info.php?products_id=41&...;osCsid=f295fa51966c4cc1ccb021aaff82597f
http://www.therss.com/creepychristine/

name: Antiquity Trivia Game
description: A trivia game on antiques and collectibles. Questions are given in three levels of difficulty: browser, buff, and advanced collector. Each player chooses a level at the beginning of the game, thus allowing experts to play with beginners. Each card has a relatively easy question (1 point if correct) and a relatively difficult question (2 points if correct). Players announce their intention to answer the easy or difficult question before the next card is revealed. First player to 30 points wins the game.

name: Julma-Juhan piinapenkki
description: A sports trivia game that has been published in a collectible set of five decks of 50 cards each, each card with 4 questions, for a total of 1000 questions. Creator Juha Väätäinen is known as the European Champion of 5000m and 10000m running in 1971.

name: State the Facts
description: Players begin an exciting journey as they take off from any of the six airports on the board. During your tour, you'll be asked questions about the states you visit. Answer correctly and you get a colorful souvenir card for that region you're visiting. Be the first player to collect a souvenir card for all six regions and you're the winner.

name: Das Flensburger Förde Spiel
description:
The game is a commercial game, related to Monopoly, for the purpose of promoting the area of the "Flensburger Förde", a landscape in the North of Germany.
The players move around a board, which consists of 40 squares. On most of the squares are parts of companies, which can be bought. The companies have values between 1000 and 8000 Euro. Three companies are combined by a color. Whenever a player lands on a win&loss-square, he must draw a card and the wins and losses of the business year are settled. According to the outcome the players gain money or have to pay money for their companies.
As soon as one player goes bankrupt, the game ends and all company cards are sold for their original price.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Patrol Torpedo (Second Edition)
description:
Patrol Torpedo

Patrol Torpedo is a game representing tactical naval combat between coastal forces during World War II. The player assumes the role of motor torpedo or gun boat skippers and their opponents, up to and including destroyers and other small escort craft.

Game Scale and Conventions


The game is designed to be played using miniature figures and terrain. The game is generally played using figures in the scale of 1/300 or 1/600 scale.1 turn - 50 Seconds
1 cm - 25 Meters
1 Knot - 1 cm of movement
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bahnfahren macht Spaß
description: A game for families with children. The players move around the board, which consists of several pictures of trains and everything involved with them. Whenever a player hits a pictograph, he can draw one card of the 68 travel-cards. If it is a pictograph, it is placed according to its position on the board and the player can move again. Players can move with every pawn and in the end the player with the most travel-cards wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gänsemarsch
description:
A children's game, consisting of 32 cards with geese on both sides and a dice. The 32 cards are arranged in a spiral and all players start from the first card. After throwing the dice the player moves accordingly forward on the spiral. If he lands on a card, he has to turn it around and follow its instructions.
The card symbols are sometimes advantageous (e.g. take another turn), sometimes disadvantageous (e.g. sit out one turn). The players can also move other pawns of other players to move them on disadvantageous cards. Therefore it is essential to remember what text is on the backside of the cards.
